description:
Solenodon paradoxus, commonly known as the Hispaniolan solenodon, is a rare and unique species of venomous mammal found only in the Dominican Republic and Haiti, located in the Caribbean region.

Belonging to the order Solenodonta, the Hispaniolan solenodon is one of the few remaining species in this order, which was once more diverse. It is a small, shrew-like creature with a long, pointed snout and distinctive features such as small eyes, large rounded ears, and a long, scaly tail.

The Hispaniolan solenodon is an insectivore, feeding primarily on insects, small vertebrates, and even small snakes. It is known for its unique venom-delivery system, which involves specialized grooves in its teeth that allow it to inject venom into its prey, making it one of the few venomous mammals on Earth.

This species is considered endangered due to habitat loss, predation by introduced species, and hunting. Conservation efforts are ongoing to protect the remaining Hispaniolan solenodon populations and their fragile island ecosystems.
